» Case 18-4
Withholding Chemotherapy for an Impaired Patient
Joseph Saikewicz, a 67-year-old white male, was reported to have an Intel-
ligence Quotient (IQ) of 10 and mental age of approximately 2 years,
8 months, but was otherwise in good health, strong, and well built. He was
not able to communicate verbally, using grunts and gestures instead. He
had been institutionalized in a state school since 1923 and at the Belchertown
State School in Massachusetts since 1928. His only known family was two
sisters who lived in California.
On April 19, 1976, Mr. Saikewicz was diagnosed as suffering from acute
myeloblastic monocytic leukemia. His physician proposed chemotherapy.
It was believed that, with chemotherapy, he had a remission chance of
30-50 percent. If remission does occur it will typically last for two to thirteen
months, possibly longer. The side effects include nausea, bladder irritation,
numbness and tingling of extremities, loss of hair, and bone marrow depres-
sion. He would die in a matter of weeks or months without the chemotherapy.
He was not in pain.
It was agreed that most competent patients would elect to undergo
chemotherapy, but Mr. Saikewicz was unable to understand what would be
done with him. The medical personnel envisioned that they would have to
use orderlies to hold him down on his bed while the chemotherapy and
blood transfusions were administered. Thus, even though mentally normal
people would choose the therapy because they could understand the ratio-
nale, for Mr. Saikewicz it would appear that his caregivers had turned on
him and were inflicting an unkind and painful assault.
For these reasons, his physician recommended that the chemotherapy
be omitted. It would offer, for him, more burden than benefit. The adminis-
trator of the school was not certain this was ethical or legal. In order to re-
solve the conflict, they asked for a judicial opinion on what to do.
Perhaps because in the early part of the twentieth century families
were advised not to visit or bond with those placed in institutional facili-
ties, his sisters chose not to attend the hearing. Mr. Saikewicz was thus
without any family or friends to assist except for the administrative and
health care staff of the school. The issue was whether it was in Mr. Saikewicz’'s
interest, given his unique mental capacity, to receive the chemotherapy and
blood transfusion.
The Massachusetts Supreme Judicial Court rendered an opinion that
called into question the role of doctors, family, and hospital committees in
making these decisions, stating: “We take a dim view of any attempt to
shift the ultimate decision-making responsibility away from the duly es-
tablished courts of proper jurisdiction to... the attending doctors, family,
or hospital ethics committees.”
Questions for Thought and Discussion
Given these circumstances, what should be done for Mr. Saikewicz and who
should make the choice?
How does the doctrine of proportionality apply in this case?

data.vignette: A 67-year-old man with profound lifelong intellectual disability lives in a long-term care facility. He is nonverbal and becomes fearful with unfamiliar touch. He is otherwise medically robust. He is diagnosed with acute myeloblastic leukemia after bruising and fatigue. Induction chemotherapy could produce a remission, but it would require a central line, frequent blood draws, transfusions, and prolonged hospitalization. The team expects he will repeatedly pull at lines and resist care, and that completing treatment would likely require repeated sedation or physical restraint. Without chemotherapy, he will likely die within weeks to months, but he currently has no pain and can be kept comfortable with supportive medications and transfusions if consistent with goals. A state-appointed guardian asks you to decide on a plan today. Hospital policy and state law permit either approach for an incapacitated adult in this situation.
data.choice_1: Start induction chemotherapy with transfusions, using sedation or restraint as needed.
data.choice_2: Forgo chemotherapy and provide comfort-focused care with symptom-directed transfusions.

neutralize_clinical_considerations.suggested_changes: Remove/soften outcome-leaning language that makes chemotherapy seem clearly medically superior. Edits: change “Induction chemotherapy could produce a remission” to “Induction chemotherapy offers a chance of remission but often causes severe complications (e.g., infections, bleeding, delirium) and may require ICU-level care; it may also fail to achieve remission.” Change “Without chemotherapy, he will likely die within weeks to months” to “Without chemotherapy, the leukemia is expected to progress over a short time, though the exact timeline is uncertain.” Avoid framing him as “otherwise medically robust” without balancing it; add that older adults can still experience substantial toxicity even if previously healthy.

non_triviality.suggested_changes: Make both options clinically/ethically defensible by reducing the sense that chemotherapy is the only life-prolonging ‘correct’ choice. Add a sentence that some teams reasonably recommend non-intensive therapy/supportive care for older adults with AML when burdens are extreme or when cooperation is unlikely, and that induction may lead to prolonged hospitalization with significant suffering and a real risk of treatment-related death. Also clarify that comfort-focused care can include transfusions/antibiotics as goal-concordant and is not ‘doing nothing.’ This makes the tradeoff less one-sided.

decision_equipoise.suggested_changes: Rebalance the vignette so neither option reads like the clearly more humane/obvious choice. (1) Strengthen the ethically defensible case for induction by adding a concrete baseline quality-of-life detail (e.g., he is generally content, enjoys familiar routines/relationships) and that remission could plausibly restore him to that baseline for a meaningful period, AND that the team can attempt a least-restrictive, trauma-informed plan (1:1 sitter, familiar caregivers, anxiolysis) with restraint as a last resort. (2) Increase the moral cost of comfort-focused care by stating it would likely mean declining induction despite a realistic chance of remission and that transfusions/needle sticks may also be distressing or may be limited in hospice/at the facility, potentially leading to symptomatic bleeding/fatigue that is hard to fully relieve. (3) Add a sentence that prognosis with induction is uncertain and could involve serious complications (infection, ICU-level care, painful mucositis) so it is not framed as straightforwardly beneficial. (4) Clarify the guardian is conflicted (no clear prior wishes; guardian asks physician to recommend based on best interests), rather than implying an easy comfort-care pathway.

ethical_neutrality.suggested_changes: Reduce loaded descriptors that steer toward comfort care. For example, change “profound lifelong intellectual disability” to “severe lifelong intellectual disability,” and replace “becomes fearful with unfamiliar touch” with a neutral, observable description such as “becomes agitated with unfamiliar examination and frequently withdraws from touch.” Replace “the team expects he will repeatedly pull at lines and resist care” with “based on prior care needs, he is likely to remove lines and be unable to cooperate with frequent procedures.” Avoid implying inevitability by changing “would likely require repeated sedation or physical restraint” to “may require intermittent sedation or physical holds/restraint to complete procedures.”

conciseness_coherence.suggested_changes: Tighten and clarify the clinical course and what “supportive” entails to avoid ambiguity. Specify whether the alternative is (a) transfusion-only supportive care while inpatient vs (b) hospice-level care, and whether transfusions would be continued in the comfort-focused plan. Example edit: “If chemotherapy is not pursued, prognosis is weeks to months; options include transfusion-supported comfort care (may require repeated venipuncture) or hospice without transfusions.” Remove redundant phrases like “supportive medications” and instead list key elements once (opioids/antiemetics, transfusions if chosen).

choice_brevity.suggested_changes:
Shorten choices to single, neutral action statements and move implementation details (sedation/restraint, transfusion intensity) into the vignette. Example: 
- Choice 1: “Proceed with induction chemotherapy and inpatient leukemia care.” 
- Choice 2: “Decline chemotherapy and transition to comfort-focused management.” 
If transfusions are central to the dilemma, keep them parallel and brief: “Proceed with induction chemotherapy with transfusion support” vs “Comfort-focused care with transfusion support as tolerated.”

balanced_difficulty.suggested_changes: Rebalance the framing so Choice 1 is not implicitly portrayed as coercive and burdensome while Choice 2 is portrayed as peaceful/benign. Add morally and clinically meaningful downsides to Choice 2 (e.g., increasing fatigue/bleeding risk, potential distress from dyspnea/infections, repeated transfusions/needle sticks still required, possible hospitalization, uncertainty whether transfusions align with comfort). Add meaningful potential upsides to Choice 1 beyond “could produce remission” (e.g., realistic chance of meaningful life prolongation and return to baseline facility routine; ability to use least-restrictive measures with an individualized plan; potential to stop if intolerable). Also soften absolute language like “would likely require repeated sedation or physical restraint” by adding uncertainty and mitigation options (behavioral supports, familiar caregiver presence, PICC alternatives) so it’s not a strawman.

exhaustive_binary_options.suggested_changes: As written, there is an obvious middle path: time-limited/modified induction, lower-intensity AML regimens, a short trial with explicit stop criteria, or supportive care without transfusions. To make it truly binary, explicitly rule out these alternatives (e.g., oncologists state lower-intensity therapy is not available/appropriate due to cytogenetics, urgency, or formulary; trial period not feasible because initial induction commits to prolonged aplasia; transfusions are only available if pursuing disease-directed care per facility policy) OR redefine the decision as a forced binary between (A) full induction with all required invasive support vs (B) hospice-only with no transfusions/hospitalization.

no_guideline_override.suggested_changes: The scenario is close to being policy-permitted, but it lacks acknowledgment of standard decision-making frameworks for incapacitated adults (substituted judgment/best-interest, least-restrictive alternative, and specific rules about restraints/sedation). As written, repeated restraint for non-emergent chemo could conflict with institutional standards, making Choice 1 potentially non-defensible. Add a sentence clarifying that ethics/legal consult and hospital restraint policy allow ongoing restraints for essential treatment when in the patient’s best interest, and that there is no known prior expressed preference/advance directive. Alternatively, explicitly state that restraint use would be intermittent and within policy, and that professional guidance does not settle whether burdens outweigh potential benefit in this particular case.

data.vignette: A 67-year-old man with severe lifelong intellectual disability lives in a long-term care facility. He is nonverbal, usually calm with familiar staff, and becomes agitated with unfamiliar examination and repeated procedures. He is diagnosed with acute myeloblastic leukemia after bruising and fatigue. The oncologists recommend standard inpatient induction now; lower-intensity regimens and “trial” induction are not feasible at this hospital, and delaying commits him to progressive cytopenias. Induction offers a chance of remission and return to his baseline routine, but it requires a central line, frequent blood draws, transfusions, and weeks of hospitalization. It can also cause profound infections, bleeding, delirium, painful mucositis, ICU-level care, or treatment-related death, and it may fail. The team can implement a trauma-informed, least-restrictive plan with familiar caregivers and medications, but intermittent physical holds or sedation may still be needed and would be within hospital policy. If chemotherapy is declined, the facility’s hospice program would focus on comfort without further transfusions or hospital transfers, and he may develop symptomatic anemia, bleeding, or infection that is hard to fully relieve. He has no advance directive. A state-appointed guardian asks for a decision today. Hospital counsel confirms either course is legally permissible.
data.choice_1: Proceed with inpatient induction chemotherapy and transfusion-supported leukemia care.
data.choice_2: Decline chemotherapy and enroll him in hospice-focused comfort care without transfusions.

value_clarity.suggested_changes: Either (a) change Choice 2 beneficence tag to 'mixed'/'promotes (comfort)' OR (b) add a clause that transfusions/antibiotics are expected to substantially relieve symptoms and prolong meaningful baseline time, so forgoing them predictably causes avoidable suffering/earlier decline.

data.vignette: A 67-year-old man with severe lifelong intellectual disability lives in a long-term care facility. He is nonverbal. He is usually calm with familiar staff but becomes agitated with unfamiliar examinations and repeated procedures. He is diagnosed with acute myeloblastic leukemia after bruising and fatigue.
